50957392.review:
XERA: Survival is a post-apocalyptic first-person shooter game developed by a single individual. The game takes place in a world ravaged by a deadly virus that has transformed the majority of the population into mindless mutants. The game presents players with an interesting and engaging storyline that provides a good framework for the gameplay.

However, despite the potential, the execution falls short in several areas. The game suffers from numerous technical issues such as bugs and glitches. The game's graphics and sound effects also leave a lot to be desired, with the overall quality feeling like something out of a game from a decade ago. The lack of diversity in enemy types and the limited number of weapons available also detracts from the overall experience. One of the biggest issues with the game is its lack of content and replayability. The game can feel repetitive after a few hours, with the same objectives and enemies appearing in almost every level. There is also a lack of variety in the environment, which can make the game feel monotonous.

Despite these criticisms, it's important to remember that XERA: Survival is a one-person project. The developer has created a game that has a lot of potential and ambition, but the limitations of working alone are evident. The fact that a single person was able to develop a game of this scope is impressive, and it's worth supporting indie developers who take on such daunting tasks.

In conclusion, XERA: Survival is a game that has a lot of flaws and limitations. However, it's also a game that has potential and is worth playing if you can look past its shortcomings. The game's one-person development team deserves recognition for their efforts and creativity, and supporting indie developers is always a worthy endeavor. If you're a fan of post-apocalyptic games and are looking for a new experience, give XERA: Survival a chance.

50920152.review:
For the dev to read: 

The game is incredibly well optimised. It is insane to get 144fps in an early acces game. 
Movements feels smooth pvp as well. I love all the events (airdrop,compound event etc.). 
You can stash your extra gear and drop out of an helicopter to avoid players camping safe zones.

Here are the cons and my suggestions:

- Full servers make everything laggy
- buildings feel empty and sometimes towns look the same 
- too many pistols in military zones
- Compass should be top center of the screen. In an action game you don't have that much time to callout and looking far left for the compass is not optimal.
- 1pp servers are a must. 3pp is fun but the fact that you can see people while they can't is a bit busted
- light armor and heavy are too close (12% vs 18%) when helmets are perfect
- Airfield feels empty
- Military zones look the same
- quad is too laggy

I enjoyed playing a lot and i'm looking forward to the next update.

51059147.review:
I initially purchased this game due to nostalgic throwbacks to warz/iss after watching some gameplay and wanted to experience some old moments once again (excluding the migraine inducing sheer rage moments caused by Sergei and Artemis).

After downloading the game and loading into a server, I was pleased to see the same antics players did back in warz were being utilized in Xera. However, after wandering around for a couple hours and exploring the map, there [i]really[/i] isn't much to do.

The towns are empty.
The majority of buildings that you'd want to get into to setup a nice ambush or have a vantage point are inaccessible.
The buildings that you can get into such as houses are bare and empty with a bag of chips in the corner or a can of soda upstairs in the closet.
The main city is generic with absolutely no reason to go there. No loot worth mentioning, minimal AI, no players.
Don't curse. Seriously. My buddy called me a cunt in chat and was instantly banned.
The ATV, the only vehicle in the game is buggy.
[list] 
[*]Stuck on a pebble? Can't get out.
[*]Hit a hescos near the roadblock? Get catapulted into the air and experience being challenger 2.0.
[*]Have a player with a 1911 sneeze on you? Explode into a ball of furious flaming hilarity.
[*]Engage a team of 3-5 players and gotta get the hell outta dodge cause you goofed your opener? Too bad since the ATV has a mind of its own and will only go 2.5mph resulting in the initial confusion getting you killed and teabagged.
[/list]

Player interaction i.e. pvp is regulated to around safe zones or at the airport and/or military base. Only areas worth looting are airport and military (with an occasional visit to the roadblocks). Compound "event" is pointless since the moment the fist turns red (indicating someone is there and it is in progress) you will have multiple people whether teamed or solo camp outside on the hills until you are finished looting to murder your face the moment you step outside and turn the area into a mini battle royal while everyone scrambles to get to your corpse. (No joke the first time this happened, the sheer volume of rounds hitting my ragdolling corpse from every direction made me think of murphys execution scene from the original Robocop)

Airdrops are an interesting addition. Usually results in players setting up an ambush point near a dropped crate and raping your face as you wait the ten seconds to open it. (I did it too. Its easy loot.)

I had a run in with what I thought was a cheater. Teleporting around to better flanking positions, getting the drop on me from the complete opposite direction from which I initially engaged him/her. Turns out it wasn't a cheater but the developer himself [b]*drum roll*[/b] JOSHUA.
This person is quite full of himself with an arrogant attitude. When called out on it, he denied everything and told me I quote "if you don't like it refund the game" then proceeded to spam "LUL" to my further complaints. I'm actually surprised I wasn't banned.

I know its early access and the general issues I currently have with the game will be worked on in the near future(will it?). But after my experience with the lead honcho himself, I highly doubt this game will progress far. Infestation: Survivor Stories is a polished masterpiece compared to this steaming pile of shit. (This is the only "praise" you'll ever get from me Sergei. Fuck you Artemis. Kill yourself)

Thanks again for your feedback, and we are constantly working on ways to improve the game.

Cheers!

51055625.review:
While I write a bad review, I want to remind everyone reading it that this is my experience with the Dev team and the game play.

The game is a ton of fun, it brings a lot of good qualities from other games while taking out the bad qualities. The combat isn't horrible, actually it is quite good (considering it is still in early access). There isn't bullet drop but there is damage drop off (newly added). Recoil is there but it's currently bugged (tied to FPS).
There are some bugs; FPS drop removes/decreases recoil, the ATV will bug out quite often (move slow, unable to get out if stuck on a rock, etc), there are also some bugs with items such as logging with attachments on weapons will still be attached but not actually on the weapon and issues with the heli and items.

The really bad part about this game, and my experience with it is the Dev team (specifically Joshua, the creator). While playing in a game on the live server, I saw someone standing still and shot and killed them (as everyone would). Then I got killed by JOSHUA who then looted my body and his friends body (presumably a dev). However, after dying my teammate engaged Joshua pushing him back to a tree where Joshua then teleported away. I confronted him in game text chat, where Joshua tried to deny it, but then confessed to teleporting. I expressed my disconcern for the game due to his actions, he then tried to defend his actions saying he teleported away to test a rock glitch. He got upset and left the server, said I can go ahead and request a refund and that he didn't care. While I felt, before this event, that the game had huge hopes and was a ton of fun to play, the actions of the creator and development team is super disconcerning. If the creator of the game cares so little that he is willing to cheat and doesn't care about it, on public servers, rather then "testing bugs" on a private server. Makes you wonder if he really cares about the game and it's future, or if he even cares about other people cheating (which I have recorded and sent to their dev team). 

Needless to say, I would not recommend this game and I would even suggest that steam consider reviewing the publisher and consider removing them from steam, I think that this game will die and become a major out-cry for people who buy it thinking that the game has hopes, when in truth the game will probably die due to the creator not caring anymore. And steam will get flooded with requests for refunds.

I do hate to give this game a bad review, I love playing it and I thought that the dev team being involved with the players could make the game a huge success, but my interaction with Joshua forces me to think otherwise.

OVERALL: Thumbs Down! 100%, The current route the game is going and the actions and response of the "ONLY" developer (and his team) are not conductive to an enjoyable game. I suggest you avoid this and that steam cuts this publisher off.

Additional update: Now that the developer (Joshua) has changed his response again, lying about what happened I feel that it goes to show how this 'team' feels about the development of this game. I would remind Joshua that no abusive messages were written in the in-game chat by myself. In truth, we did not know that they were admins as there is no way to tell until you confirmed it in chat and teleporting away from a fight after looting a player that you killed because you had god mode on is cheating in just about every sense of the word. Which, by the way, is in violation of the Value developer community terms of use regarding Conduct on the sites as this would be classed as a "functionality that may give a player an unfair competitive advantage when playing multiplayer".

101586125.review:
After playing for a few hours I realize a couple of PROS and CONS about this arcade day-z looter shooter.
Some things may change if you play with friends (I played Solo my first couple gameplays)

PVP AND GUNPLAY
The hit reg seems alright, not bad for an early access game but the looting is so painful, having to scroll through the persons entire inventory seems very stupid and in most cases would get you killed. Guns are easy to find which I enjoy, attachments work and are very plentiful as well. 

THE MAP
The map is huge which in some cases is good but it makes playing very boring and lonely. Pvp interaction is pretty rare even on a full pop server. Most of the cities have copied and pasted buildings and contain very little loot making going there an extreme waste of time.

THE AI
Props to them for not using zombies and having their own unique thing, but there is very little Ai interaction adding on to the loneliness of the game.
I didn't even know there were any other A.I other than robots until I was looting and heard gunshots coming from a "bandit" that seemed to be the only thing that was in the city.

BASE BUILDING
After rounding up a couple of tools that seemed to be needed for a proper base build I decided to try it out. I feel like this could be easily fixed but WHY is it so hard to find a spot to build a base. Not even kidding I spent almost an hour running around the map trying to find an area to build.
-
 When I finally found a decent spot to build i placed down the flag thing and got to building. I personally dont really mind the building and individually placing down each base frame but I feel it requires so much grinding to get even a simple 1x1 set up. Traps and Turrets are very cool addition either buying or finding the parts to craft one. Overall its very easy to understand but just really inconvenient in some cases.

EVENTS 
I like the constant events going around the map like Airdrops and Helicopter crashes. It really spices things up and gives the player something to do other than just looting and killing other people. These events provide very good loot and gives a very big challenge to people.


Overall id give this game a 6/10 its not the best, but its not the worst either. Fun game to hop on if you are looking for an arcade looter shooter similar to H1Z1 Just Survive (games a mix of Dayz and Rust)

This is my first real review on a game so if there is anything I could improve please leave a comment.

55694534.developer_response:
Our development tools are quite useful when tracking bugs and getting around the map looking at issues that players report. They are also quite useful for tracking cheaters and players who break our code of conduct. These tools are only available to 3 staff on the team, including myself, our Community Manager (Gary) and our new developer (Reuben) who just joined the team about a month ago. These tools are strictly locked to hard-coded Steam accounts.

While we would love to play and PvP, the truth is we just don’t get the time to do so. Even if we did have the time – we would definitely not use these tools against our players. Each of our staff do have alt accounts which have the same privileges as a normal player (no dev tools) – for the rare occasion of when we do jump into the wild and play. Other than that – when we are on dev accounts, we are in talking with our players, helping out new players or checking game-servers for lag and other issues.

These allegations of us using these tools to “win” – what really would we have to gain? We have access to all the loot we would ever need and have a dedicated testing environment away from the live environment. Using these tools would honestly do nothing for us. 

Additionally - We actually track a lot of useful information, including the kills / deaths of players. This data is never wiped for security purposes. Based on this data the user in question “Axliam” never had any PvP encounters with a developer or any of our staff in-game. As you can see here: https://i.imgur.com/sX11ruk.png 

As for bans - we have a very strict code of conduct which players can find themselves breaking when being toxic in the heat of the moment. Generally, bans go in the order of: 24 Hours, 48 Hours, 72 Hours, 7 Days, 14 Days, 30 Days - depending on the infraction and the severity. You can find our code of conduct on our support portal here: https://support.xeragame.com/hc/en-us/articles/360024225574

I hope this clears up any misinformation, feel free to reach out to me directly at joshua@spottedkiwi.nz if you have any questions.

I also encourage anyone with any concerns or questions to jump into our Discord and have a chat with us. Our Discord provides you with direct access to our staff and we typically reply within a few hours. https://discord.gg/xera

Regards,
Joshua

120997783.review:
The best way i can describe this game in its current state is... Annoying. Its a truly unfortunate review, because its so close to being good.

Most of the stuff i take issue with could just be tweaked, major changes are not needed.

The Gunplay - Honestly, the best part of this. Though most guns kick too much to use in first person, they work pretty good in third person. The most annoying part of the weaponry is the durability. You can run three or four mags through an ar-15 and nearly be done with the thing, even coming at 75% dura. There is a repair system, and a nearly useless weapon level system, but finding a new weapon is much easier than finding the tools and materials to repair a weapon that does 0.2% more damage. 

The looting - Dear god the looting, tedium at its finest. Most of it is holding e to search crates, and getting the notification its empty. When you do find something, its never exciting. Even looting through military locations, half the crates have a single screwdriver, or wrench, or other redundant tool/mele weapon. When its not loot you already have, or a single water bottle, you might get lucky enough to get a few bullets or a gun, not like those bullets are going to last you long.


The Enemies - The most annoying part, Dayz syndrome at its finest. The most basic enemy taking 5-7 bullets to take down. You could always use mele, but there isnt a reliable way to avoid damage when doing this. The enemies are somewhat unique, Robots that take more damage when you shoot them in the glowing core, right in the middle of their chest. Coming in three glitchy variants. 
Red - The most basic, found everywhere across the map. Taken down with relative ease, and not dealing that much damage. Though when i say "ease" I do mean dumping 10 bullets into their chest and hoping that their jagged, super fast movements didn't bob their core too much.
Blue - What usually would be called the Hunters, or something of the sort. Higher health, much higher damage, spawns only at night (and certain monuments) and barely gets staggered. These things can take nearly a 30 round mag of 9mm right to their core all the while charging you down. 
Green - The tank. And the most annoying of all. These things are truly tanks, Mega high health, Mega high damage, and an armored exterior protecting their cores. There is no way to solo these things without glitching them. No matter the armor your wearing, they WILL three shot you. They will run just as fast as all the other bots, taking fire from 2-3 people, and NEVER STOP. they will never get staggered, never slow down. The only true thing to fear in this game.

Q : So, how do you deal with these bots? 
A : well, it seems as if the Blue and Green droids cant open doors, so if your looting higher teir areas, most places with doors are safe havens. 
Q : Well okay, but what if i want to kill them? Bring ammo. You think you have enough? Wrong. These things take MAGS of ammo to take down, especially if you want to kill the tanks. 
Q : Well okay, I have ammo, what now? G L I T C H E S. DO NOT take these droids on fairly. Trap them behind doors, exploit their AI so they cant hit you on a table, keep shooting them so they loop in the same spot when they cant reach you. This is true TENFOLD for the tanks. They will kill you in moments, you cant stagger them, and you run slower than them with your guns out. 

So, what do i suggest? well, 
- Increase weapon damage/Decrease droid health. Pvp felt alright in regards with weapon damage, just the droids are annoying.
- Change looting a bit, either decrease the amount of item crates, or make it so that things actually spawn in the crates. And change looting tables a bit. I don't want to be finding metal pipes in a gun crate, and guns in a materials warehouse.
- Update the enemies, i'm talking new animations, new path finding, generally a new polish. With the way they move, Its hard to hit them most of the time. Mainly attributed to the fact they don't have a turning animation. All they do is kind of magically pop over to where they need to look, and for movement all they really have is a basic walking animation, and a basic running/angered animation. But even when they have spotted you the most they can do now is walk at you in a straight line and try and "hit" you with a janky animation. Its not clear whether they can actually hit you from where your standing, if you can strafe them, or if its always going to hit. There should also be something more unique to the enemies, I've got a few basic ideas.

- the cores instead of headshots is an interesting idea, although it doesn't seem like enough. Maybe instead of just dealing more damage, make it so its an insta kill, but higher tier areas add on layers of armor. You could even counteract this by adding in armor piercing ammunition for the richer players. And for tanks, they already have multiple cores. Slow them down a bit, add in a few extra moves, maybe ranged, and make it so you must shoot out all the cores to kill them. 

- You could lean into the robot idea a bit more, Shoot off limbs to cripple them, then move in for the kill. Make different weapons more effective for this. For example, the shotgun isnt great as it is... But if it has the potential to blow off an arm or leg in one shot? Well now, that's great! take an axe to the knee? Maybe it wont chop off a solid steel leg, but it can damage it! Slow robots down to make it easier to kill them. you can go pretty far with this.

- make these things DANGEROUS. Decrease spawns, but make it so any one of these things could kill you. The most basic enemy as it is, well you can just punch it out with your flimsy little flesh arms. These things could be the killing machines they're made out to be, and if you dont come prepared, and shoot accurately, your completely done for.

- Lean heavier on the stealth end, maybe the front end is tankier, but the back has a large core that will stun or kill them. or sneaking up to them with an axe, or a new specialized hacking device is an insta kill. you can even go so far as to add a reverse targeting device. Use that tank to clear out the rest of the monument, or DESTROY YOUR ENEMIES!  

Theres so many things that this game can do to make it great, but its just uninspired. Basic. Tired and done before.
But it is playable. Passable for a free game. Just be ready for a ton of jank.

This game is great for people with lots of time, it's incredibly grindy and fun for a time. One of the biggest issues I have is that it is exceedingly difficult to get anything better than a UMP-9 or a MP5 once you manage to get something like a G36 or one of the 2 types of scars you will get killed by someone with thousands of hours and they'll take everything you own, and your dignity. It has AI in the form of purely melee only robots who you can outrun with ease and cheese them with a buggy so they can't hit you, and it has "bandits" that are not worth the trouble finding or doing a Reactor Core event for unless you have a mission to kill them. The game-play is very linear in it's progression until you need to find any of the USBs needed to progress further. The Civilian Bunker Data USB is impossible to find from helicopter crashes (which is the only place I managed to find it) and only gives you access to a bunker that gives higher tier weapons, of which you will definitely lose instantly. The other 3 USB sticks are for one thing called the Crater that give next to nothing unless you get a level 3 access to mine Xoidite-H ore to make the only explosive in the game that does any noticeable damage to structures and even if you get it, it is confined to one server so you can only raid on one server. That's ONLY if you manage to find ANY of the Crater USBs. The only real way to get any of the USBs for the Crater is to buy them from the Survivor Exchange (a player driven economy where people can buy items and sell what they find) for exorbitant prices that are unachievable for the average player. That's only the start, farming for a base is VERY tedious and getting a wood base is easy enough, but getting anything more than that, like a stone or metal base, you have to farm for hours. The only stone/metal/sulfur/copper/silver/gold mining tool is a pickaxe (besides the wood and stone variants) that can be a ground pickup or be found in a box. The servers pretty much wipe once a year, so good luck against all the other multi-thousand hour players who have no life and have had months and months to build up and get gear. Raiding is damn near impossible as I hinted at earlier in the review, with a very limited selection to raid with including Xoidite Explosive Charges, C4, and grenades. Doing 500, 150, and 25 damage respectively with a basic wood wall having 500 health you can see the difficulty in raiding. One of the only good aspects are the 3 modes of transportation, a non-controllable helicopter that travels between the Settlements, a one seater ATV, and a 3 seater buggy. One of the main problems that are stated in other reviews is the extremely low playerbase so i won't go into too much detail on that. 

TLDR:

Don't bother unless you have 5 friends to play with.

This renders the game unplayeable, since enemies can walk into your base and take all your grinding profits. The devs dont seem very interested in looking into this, despite multiple players reporting this issue. I uninstalled the game for now, will be back if this issue is completely fixed. 

UPDATE END, original positive review below:

Nice survival grinding game with the typical friendly, helpful and toxic players in appropriate proportions. The game has still a lot of QOL to be improved, and the tiny dev team is working hard on it. 

Xera: Suirvival is a chill game for those who like to loot, grind and get kicks from finding the rarer supplies. The tech tree is straight forward and manageable. At first the objective of the game is not quite clear. Yet it is simple, like in any survival game: to live long and prosper. 

So at first you start with the very basic stick collecting and food gathering. After you got the basic tools and weapons you start to feel the need to settle down. You will want to establish a base for protection of yourself and the precious, hard earned belongings. At your base you can also upgrade and mend your gear, as well as craft gear that cannot be found in the world like C4 explosives. To get your basic base and gear set up takes about 10-15 hours gaming time. 

After a lot of hours and making some battle buddies, you are ready to go out and raid other player's bases. Or you can focus on being a hedgehog and create the impenetrable fortress. Or you can complete the challenges around the map to get rewards like better weapons and armor.

The game offers sufficient amount of action for those who want to fight. But before you get to this point, you'll want to get at least some body armor and something else than a handgun!

55697272.developer_response:
Hi there!

Thanks so much for trying the game out during the free weekend!

The AR-15 takes .223 rounds, this is so we can control the spawn rate. It is also because the AR-15 can take different rounds. 

"The difference in the round itself: the NATO round is a little hotter. The case is the same size, but the powder charge, projectile and also rifle specifications differ. As a result, make sure to check your AR-15 to see which it’s chambered for, as not all AR-15 rifles sold to civilians are the same."

"The standard loading is NATO SS109 (aka M855) which uses a 62-grain projectile. The powder charge for that round is on the hot side, which is loaded to chamber pressures around 62,400 psi in a rifle chambered for 5.56mm NATO. In a rifle chambered for .223 Remington, the round produces chamber pressures upward of 70,000 psi, if going by SAAMI (the Sporting Arms and Ammunition Manufacturers Institute) standards.

By contrast, .223 Remington tends to produce lower chamber pressures between 52,000 and 55,000 psi, going by SAAMI specs. Therefore, 5.56mm NATO ammo isn’t safe for use in a rifle chambered for .223 Remington, but .223 is OK in 5.56. Thus, powder charge is the main difference between 5.56 vs .223 cartridges."

Feel free to read more on the difference here: https://www.thetruthaboutguns.com/5-56-vs-223/

Hope this clears it up!

Cheers

78326225.review:
[h1] The Machine Takeover: DayZ With Robots [/h1]

[b] Who Will Like It [/b]: Those who enjoy survival games with permanent item loss (DayZ & SCUM) but prefer a more arcade-y feel and smaller map.

[b] Who Won't Like It [/b]: Those who want more tactical combat, a larger map, or don't enjoy fighting robotic enemies.

It's easy to see screenshots of XERA: Survival and immediately think it's another "survival crafting asset flip". I bought it with extremely low expectations and can honestly say that I was dumbfounded by the quality and attention to detail. 

So what is it? XERA is an open world survival game with PvP and PvE elements. It's primary gameplay loop is similar to that of DayZ, except on a much smaller and "arcade-y" scale. The map is generously filled with loot, robotic enemies (Humanoids), and in-game events that trigger periodically over the course of your session. These events add a very "alive" touch to what could have otherwise been a very static game world. They are broadcasted frequently through your comm system and add optional (and rewarding) challenges to your session.

Your character gains experience for every action (looting, killing enemies, completing events, etc) and levels accordingly. Players have two "Base Camps" that act as HUBS where they can deposit looted items into a Global Stash for safekeeping, purchase/sell items, repair equipment, and pay for a helicopter ride across the map. These HUBS also act as safezones and recharge hunger, thirst, and health levels while inside. 

Death in XERA is not as frustrating as it's predecessors. Upon being killed, all loot/gear is dropped and can be reclaimed within 15 minutes of respawning. Death does not reset your character level, nor does it deduct items from your Global Stash. This system adds a very refreshing "mobility" and "permanence" to a genre where headshots usually end 15 hours of progress and start you from scratch.

It performs fantastically too. Only in very rare instances did I encounter frame drops and usually maintained 60-70 FPS throughout. Character motion is fluid and can seemlessly alternate between 1st and 3rd person viewpoints. Firearms are abundant and pack a fun punch against the robotic foes, who often amass in large numbers, especially in the denser areas.

XERA also has an extremely generous crate system that rewards the player with weapon cosmetics each time a level is gained. I typically despise when games implement this, but here, it isn't stupidly obnoxious or greedy. The option to purchase crates is there, but not in your face. Lots of awesome skins are gained just by playing, with the option to even grab some through the Steam Marketplace at insanely low prices. I ended up grabbing 2 or 3 Halloween skins that cost about 12 cents each. 

Lastly, I cannot praise the development team enough here. They are extremely responsive in forums and Discord to any and all feedback. In a few occasions, they even hopped into my server just to chat and wish me a fun session. As an indie dev team, this communication goes a long way in establishing trust with a consumer. From what I have seen, these guys love what they do, and it shows in their interaction with the players. Hats off to the team.

The only downside here is the low player base. That being said, the small community that is routinely active is extremely friendly and a joy to play with. It is my hope that more players gravitate toward the game as it continues improving.

Would I recommend XERA? Absolutely. It's a fresh take on the survival genre: One that is not obnoxiously large, difficult, or punishing as those before it. It offers a wealth of things to do and smooth gameplay to make those things enjoyable. It offers themed events (with themed loot) and is backed by a staff of passionate and friendly gamers that love what they do. As long as the low player count is not a turn off, you are in for one wild and satisfying ride.

78500791.developer_response:
Hi there,

Thanks for taking the time to write a review. It’s unfortunate that you cannot see the end goal for the design of the game. As you mention – the upcoming content is listed on our roadmap. Although we don’t go into exact detail on all the upcoming features due to competition – but I can assure you that everything that we work on we attempt to add to the genre, rather than copy. We are always working on ways to re-define the genre and I think that our implementation of base building will be a first for this genre. 

As you also mention, “lack of implementation” is just a stage of early access. Everything you mention is being worked on, including skills, base building and more crafting options. We also have a lot of PVE content on its way with base building – for example protecting your base from humanoid raids.

To answer your question – we are not following in any path of “failed games”. We have always made an attempt to be unique in any way we can – being the first survival humanoid apocalypse game for one. We have lots of other content which in your playtime (1.5 hours) you would have not come across. Our focus is progression and longevity and levelling up unlocks new content (which you would not have been able to access straight away). 

I recommend that you try the game again in Season 4 as there will be more content that will be more aligned with what you are looking for in the game.

Thanks again for trying the game out.

Regards,
Joshua

55681172.review:
Personally, for a game in alpha with only 1 man under the hood, this is actually quite a fun time.

Xera, though basic right now, still offers a small handful of things to do while the game is still in alpha.
So far I've seemed to find that there are 3 main activities. This would be grabbing supply drops, looting downed helicopters, and clearing these almost like "outposts" filled with enemies which then reward you a small bit of cash and 2 supply drops. There's also bunker events which I am yet to figure out, that require you to have a key to the bunker to gain entry and are also timed.

You will spend heaps of time on this game running around aimlessly looting random things and bringing them back to base so you may bank/sell/restock to your hearts desire. I personally find games like this, to be much more addictive with the banking system, allowing you to bring your gear to any server, and gear up at your hearts content.

The XP system isn't fantastic, and at this point in time seems quite experimental, as you gain skillpoints but have no use for them yet. Leveling does grant you a few small benefits right now, however, such as opening up some crafting recipes you can make use of on the go.

Gun play in this is practically non existent. Wherever you shoot, your bullet will travel instantly, but this is okay in a game like this. It makes PvP a little more interesting, plus makes PvE grinding a breeze when you learn the ropes. 

The character movements are rather lackluster, nothing special, same with the ATV driving mechanics, however do not let this stop you. The game is in Alpha, and as I had stated above, only have the main developer under the hood with a small supporting staff. The idea is here, and I see the effort that's starting to go into the game, so because of this I will be purchasing the game before the f2p weekend ends.

Grab a friend and give it a go, can't hurt to try it for free.
I will be following the support on this game, hope to see nice things.

123480860.review:
Over 14 hours played and my character is level 11; so can offer a quick early review.
If you’ve played RUST and many other Survival games, you’ll jump into this one easy.
Since its free and I played quite bug free and didn’t pay a cent, I can give this a thumbs up – nothing to lose by checking it out.
BUT
It needs a lot of tweaking and just more!!..., to really keep me or many others engaged for a long time.
Survival mechanics aren’t harsh; just food, drink, HP, radiation and you can run for eternity, since not needing stamina.  Which is handy because if you don’t find a limited Buggy or AV, it quickly becomes a running simulation…   Crafting is fine but I've found some issues with the progression.
Looting is OK, but I feel compared to other similar games in this genre is will likely fade in the sunset; unless they implement some amazing game play.
Besides the bots near cities and a few reindeer in couple of areas the wilderness in void of all life…. Nothing at all!   Be nice to have to run from or hunt a wild boar, wolf or something..
Since most servers are low population, players seem more on the helpful than toxic side; while great for starters, its does take away conflict and extra excitement. 
Hope the Devs give this one some much needed love & care..

51326236.review: It's an early-access game, so what does that REALLY mean? It means things are going to change. These changes might be bad, such as recoil, and if they are bad, they are reverted, as recoil was. The dev team is small, but they talk to their community to gauge what's working and what isn't. This game is like Nether, NewZ, and PUBG rolled into one, but much more polished from the start than any of those games were (even on PUBG's AAA title budget). Give them time and it'll be something fun to murder 12 year-olds on. Just give this game some time and a chance.
